title: Summary & Significance
text:
Summary & Significance

TB remains a global health challenge, with a high burden in South Africa
Understanding the genetic factors influencing the progression from LTBI to active TB is crucial for developing effective interventions
This research project aims to bridge the gap between genetic variation and protein expression in TB by mapping pQTLs in a South African cohort
This study will compare cytokine profiles and identify distinct pQTLs among individuals with LTBI, Active TB, and healthy controls
A combination of genetic and immunological analyses will be employed, including whole-genome sequencing and 27 plex Luminex assays ato quantify cytokine levels
This project has completed the analysis of sputum and blood samples to determine TB infection status using GeneXpert and IGRA assays.

title: Background:
text:
First line of defence
Alveolar macrophages encounters M.tb, phagocytose bacteria, initiates inflammation with release of TNF-⍺ | IL-1
Dendritic cells links the innate immune system and the adaptive immune system by presenting the antigens to the T Lymphocytes
Naturally Killer Cells are cytotoxic cells that induce apoptosis of infected macrophages by secreting IFN-γ





T lymphocytes, which is comprised of CD4+ & CD8+ cells, B lymphocytes
CD4+ T cells produce IFN-γ | IL-2 | TNF-⍺ to active macrophages
CD8+ T cells destroys M.tb infected cells by producing TNF-⍺
The role of B cells are being investigated

title: Background:
text:
TB is a respiratory disease caused by Mycobacterium tuberulosis (M.tb)
WHO estimates that 25% of global population is infected with M.tb
South Africa has a high burden

Definition: An individual that is infected with M.tb but has no clinical symptoms of active disease
Primary source for new TB cases
LTBI -> Active TB occurs in about 5-10% of infected individuals
Factors influencing progression: Weakened Immune system | Time since infection | Age
Exact mechanism of progression is unknown

title: Introduction to pQTL
text:
Protein Quantitive Trait Loci
pQTL specifically refers to a region of DNA that is associated with the level of quantity of a particular protein
In simple terms -> Genetic location that influences how much of a certain protein is produced by the body
Helps understand how genetic variations influence immune response by affecting protein production (cytokines)




Region of DNA that is associated with a particular quantitative trait
Essential identifies a section of genome that influences the degree to which a trait is expressed
